values:
Even if you're not a Trek fan, come click my ads!
 

It's safe to say that the majority of us are anticipating the new JJ Abrams Star Trek movie. Whether or not to anticipate it with hand-wringing dread or rapturous glee is the subject of much discussion, but one thing is for certain: you'd better bone up on your knowledge of The Original Series.

However for some of you, there's just one little problem: you hate the old Star Trek. Just thinking about those campy, polyester miniskirts and fu manchu lookin' Klingons makes you cringe.

For you dear readers, I provide you with: How to Overcome Your Hatred of Star Trek: The Original Series.

This is also the first entry in my new Blog, TrekPhobia. Expect frequent updates in the coming weeks, and go ahead and add it to your RSS reader, bookmarks, and what-not. You can also have fun clicking the Digg button, (as well as my google ads, because I'm in NYC right now, and thousands of people just lost their jobs because the stock market has gone kablooey).

Hope you like it!

My girlfriend Annie and I rented a van from U-Haul today so we could pick up some furniture at Ikea. When we were dropping off the van this afternoon, we were greeted by a large, Jamaican man in his thirties who would check us in and sign our paperwork for the van rental. As I open the door and jump out of the van, the U-Haul man says to me, "You have great appetite!" "I, uh, what now?" Do I look really fat today!? "You have great appetite!" he says again. "You have great appetite... in women!" I look toward Annie. "Oh! You think I have a pretty girlfriend!" I exclaim. "Yes yes. Great appetite. Very good". Yeah, well. I think I have pretty good taste in women too.

The most striking aspect of Man On Wire, at least in the beginning, is footage of the twin towers under construction. It is a welcome contrast to the bombardment of destruction we've become so tragically accustomed to over the past 7 years. Man On Wire is the story of how wire walker and performance artist Philippe Petit turned his dream of walking a wire between the World Trade Center into a beautiful reality. The film is presented as if it were a bank heist. It's like a real life version of Oceans Eleven, replacing cocky lounge singers with passionate, French romantics. There is no mention of the towers inevitable demise, save for a few comments from Petit and his cohorts about how they had accomplished something that could never be accomplished again. It would cheapen Petit's unbelievable (not to mention, unfathomably dangerous) work of beauty to throw in some maudlin, quasi-patriotic aside that yes; the twin towers eventually fell. By omitting what we all already know, the film serves as a joyful memorial to the stunning architecture that was the twin towers. When Philippe Petit states that he could walk between the towers because he felt as though they belonged to him, he touched on the very essence of what a monument should be. The film is emotional only on a personal level, as we are made to understand the weight of what Petit and his accomplices had achieved, and never invites the audience to mourn the absent towers. Still, one scene did manage to take ahold of my heart for a moment. A photograph showing Philippe Petit's signature on the south tower is shown during the final epilogue of the film. My immediate reaction was, "Wow, I wonder if that is still up there today"? Or course I remembered, it isn't. http://www.manonwire.com/

I'm sitting in the Sunset Park branch of The Brooklyn Museum, and something miraculous has happened. The internet has stopped working. To be accurate the network is down. The wifi is working just fine (which is how I am able to post this right now) However, what this means is dozens of six year old to ten year old kids can't log on to check their Webkins and as a result have been reduced to - do my eyes deceive me? - reading books! It's true! The children all exchange quizzical looks, unable to fathom what is transpiring. They become anxious, agitated. One little girl slowly sits down on the floor, her eyes darting wildly, as she looks up asking no one in particular, "is... is this what's like, to die?" They wander without aim until, what's this? It's colorful. The words are simple, but somehow clever. Words play with numbers; these fish, they are red, they are blue. Some children are still desperate for a fix. One little girl in a hajib, no older than six is at a computer playing with virtual blocks, aided by the guiding voice of Elmo. Another little boy, maybe seven or eight, is playing (I shit you not) MS Solitaire. Maybe this is the dawn of a new era. Maybe this is the birth of a new generation of luddites, who will take our society back to a simpler time. Maybe the fat, mustached librarian will learn better spanish, so he can come up with something better to say than, "Um... aqui, los computadora no... work-o... fuctional-li.."
Here's some cellphone pictures I've recently taken. FOR FUN! The place is starting to feel like home. Mariopoly? Mama mia! Chrono Trigger and Super Mario World. Life is somehow complete.

Riding shotgun in a Volvo sedan that smells like crayons down Smith street on our way to get Cuban sandwiches and mimosas, we pass a movie shoot. I'm still a bit sore, that the director didn't spring from his little canvas and wood directing chair and exclaim, "You there! You! With those sparkling eyes and that winning smile. I want you to be the star in my picture!"

In fact this was the second location shoot we passed in Brooklyn, and I am still, as of this moment, not a movie star. 

I can't understand it. I haven't had even one limo stop me as I stroll down the street, the opaque window lowering to reveal an impeccably dressed man, his body somewhat rotund with years of luxury, pointing at me with his imported Cuban cigar, and offering me a once-in-a-lifetime motion picture deal uttering such things as, "kid" and "name in lights". 

It's possible that I am simply far too good looking, too well dressed that all of these high powered movie types simply believe I am already a movie star. They recognize the undeniable stride of a leading man, and instruct their drivers to carry on.

Maybe I'm being unrealistic. Maybe I should remind myself that I've only been in this town a couple of weeks, and that I am already being watched by many movers and shakers in the movie biz. It's quite possible that any day now I'll receive a phone call with cryptic instructions to meet at a secret location. I'll wind up an a very upscale office, and on the desk before me will be a series of photographs - very flattering photographs - of yours truly! The man behind said desk will say, "we've been watching you for some time now Mr. Molloy. And we like what we see".

That should all be happening very soon, so If you don't hear from me after this - ever again - you'll know that I have a new life, and before you know it, you'll be watching a trailer for a new summer blockbuster staring some chiseled faced heartthrob named, "Brock Huntingston" but you'll know who Brock really is. 

See you at the premier!

Hey everyone! I'm in a Starbucks in Park Slope right now, so I'm going to make this brief before I throw up all over someone's baby! Here's a short little photo album of the first couple days in our new apartment. Enjoy!
Moving to Brooklyn

I'm watching an episode of Scooby Doo where the crew is out camping in a spooky forest, and who should they run across, but Joker and The Penguin! And you know what that means! Sure enough, Batman and Robin come swooping in on the Bat-Copter (not the stealthiest means of pursuing a suspect, say nothing of its carbon footprint) hot on the villains' heels. After mistaking Shaggy and Scoob for Joker and The Penguin, Batman and Robin decide to team up with our favorite pack of mystery soloving stoners, and as a show of good faith, Batman produces a black (I assume choclate) bat-shaped BAT-COOKIE! I understand you like cookies Bruce Wayne, everybody does. I've bought Girl Scout Cookies with rent money before, so I'm not really one to speak. And I'm assuming here that Alfred was browsing the Dollar Store with his one day off this month, (because lord knows you've ruined any chance of him having anything close to a social life) and found some halloween cookie cutters at a real bargain. But do you really need to be taking up valuable real estate in your famous utility belt for bat-cookies?

Using another Mac app that I found over at LifeHacker, I made this quick, time lapse video of an afternoon of my job as a nanny using the open source application Gawker. It's just a test really, so it's only 7 seconds long. What zips by is an afternoon where I drive, make and serve a grilled cheese sandwich, play with blocks, and drive some more. I plan on doing a longer, more comprehensive documentary of my day.

William Saletan over at Slate's Human Nature blog brings us another sign that we will all soon become bloody smears on the hydraulic claws of our robotic overlords:
If you want to get closer to the cutting edge of robotics, so to speak, you're better off looking at a technology that's already well-commercialized: robotic lawn mowers. Today's New York Times salutes a new product, the Kyodo LawnBott LB3500, which mows your lawn by itself. Here's the manufacturer's description: It operates automatically, and autonomously by means of its intelligent computer and a perimeter cable. It can move freely within an enclosed area, detecting the faint signal transmitted by the perimeter cable located on the ground, defining the areas to be mowed; it can also work without a perimeter cable as working area is enclosed by a fence or small border at least 4 inches tall. ... [I]t leaves its docking station and starts mowing your yard in a random direction. It will mow in a straight line until it bumps into an obstacle, such as a tree or flower pot, or until it runs over its perimeter cable, then it stops, backs up, turns and takes off again. Well, at least it needs a human to recharge its batteries, right? Wrong. The company explains: When the batteries start running low, or at the end of its cutting cycle, the mower will search out the perimeter cable and follow it back to its docking station to recharge. After charging, it heads back out on its own! ... With the new LawnBott, you have One Less Thing to Worry About. Well, yes. But you also have one more thing to worry about: Your lawnmower running amok while you're at the office. No human hassle means no human control.
Strangely enough, I still want a Roomba more than you can imagine. Mainly because I want to name it, and attach a gruesome halloween mask to it. What would be cooler than a little Freddie Kruger head trundling about the apartment?

The robocalypse is upon us. From the video below, it looks as though engineers have devloped a robot that can learn to knife you like a hobo. 

<lj-embed id="27" />

Look what I made!



Move over Nightmare Before Christmas, this is cinematic genius.

The video was made with a slick little app called FrameByFrame. It uses your built in iSight cam, or any other connected webcam to make stop-motion animations. It's shockingly easy, and the application is free.

The quality is obviously limited to the quality of your webcam, but since this kind of animation is so excruciatingly time consuming, it's a fun way to kill an afternoon with nothing but a MacBook and your Ninja Turtle collection.

Damnit. I just ran over my niece's little pink bike with my brother's enormous pickup truck!





   + = SHATTERED FUTURE!

Mangled. Just like my poor niece's hopes and dreams!

Ah yes, a sure sign of summer:



This is both encouraging, as well as... disturbing.

Encouraging, because, well, freezer pops are fucking awesome and cheap. When you're too poor to afford air conditioning, or even Kool-Aid, these little plastic tubes of heaven are where it's at. A giant bin of these things is a sure sign that summer is on it's way.

Disturbing because, well, it's a giant bin of freezer pops just heaped in the center of Wal*Mart's sporting goods department. I have unsettling images in my head of droves of Wal*Mart shoppers (not you and I mind you, but those Wal*Mart shoppers. You know the ones), pawing at freezer pops, like hordes of the undead languidly clutching the entrails of a fresh kill.

Also:



Oink oink, little boy! You want fries with that? I think you've got enough tubes of sugar water with out having to lust after your sister's freezer pops with your gaping, fucking steak-hole!

Living out here in the sticks, it's always a sight to see the tall brown profile of a UPS truck, trundling it's way down our winding, wooded, dirt road. It's a lot of effort for a small package, and the exasperation all over the driver's face let me know so much. Who cares?! I got my brand new J. Fold "magic wallet"! More about my switch from a bulky, back pocket wallet, to this slim and sexy dealie, and what makes it so magic, after the jump. On your left is my old wallet, a big ol' Paul Frank, that I've used for the past few years now. In addition to being held together primarily with duct tape, secreting an oily film, and being offensive to seniors who fought against communism in past, foreign wars - it's bulky. Way too bulky for a short, assless, skinny guy. The thing that makes this so "magic", are the little elastic straps that are set up like a jacob's ladder. You simply place the money in the open wallet, close it, open it again and voila! your cash is securely strapped in place. Not only is it easy to throw your cash in your wallet quickly, it's easy to keep it organized, and draw out one bill at a time. One of the main reasons I got this wallet, was for riding the subway. Not only can I keep this securely fit in my front pocket -free from the wandering fingers of pick-pocketers- but it makes grabbing my MetroCard a cinch. It also makes it less likely that it's going to bounce around in my suit jacket pocket, ultimately wandering away to MetroCard Island (where cards with money still on them live out the rest of their days in despair) As far as embracing the idea that my wallet is not a filing cabinet, it's surprisingly freeing. I really don't need six dozen business cards, pictures, crumpled phone numbers that belong to someone I don't recall ever meeting, or my expired ACLU card. I carry a man bag anyway, so I can simply use an Altoids tin, or a small "accordion style" pouch for receipts and other miscellanea. Oh yes Mr. UPS driver, it was totally worth it.

Ever since I've got ShapeShifter for Mac, I have been on a quest to find the perfect theme for OS X. Something simple and dark, functional, and didn't look like The Matrix exploded all over my hard drive.

After poring over a lot of themes, icon sets, and backgrounds, this is where I'm at:


Click here for larger version

The Dock background has been removed, and the icons are a mix of a system wide theme, some odd icons I found around the internet, and the Firefox, Photo Booth and Flickr icons I made myself.


Click here for larger version

Above is what a typical open window looks like.


Click here for larger version

The dark theme, and consistency of color makes whatever I'm working on or watching really pop. It's a great way for me to keep focused.

So there's a peek at my computer. I'm so sorry.

And not just any devil, but some sort of freaky cat devil! Mee-fuckin'-yow, bitches!

You are The Devil

Materiality. Material Force. Material temptation; sometimes obsession

The Devil is often a great card for business success; hard work and ambition.

Perhaps the most misunderstood of all the major arcana, the Devil is not really "Satan" at all, but Pan the half-goat nature god and/or Dionysius. These are gods of pleasure and abandon, of wild behavior and unbridled desires. This is a card about ambitions; it is also synonymous with temptation and addiction. On the flip side, however, the card can be a warning to someone who is too restrained, someone who never allows themselves to get passionate or messy or wild - or ambitious. This, too, is a form of enslavement. As a person, the Devil can stand for a man of money or erotic power, aggressive, controlling, or just persuasive. This is not to say a bad man, but certainly a powerful man who is hard to resist. The important thing is to remember that any chain is freely worn. In most cases, you are enslaved only because you allow it.

I also love telling my 4 year old niece, "Did you know that Uncle Pat used to have the same color hair as Stephanie when he was in high school?"

I'm lucky to have a girlfriend who loves Law & Order as much as I do. She's more into the SVU, and I'm all about Jack McCoy, but it's all around pretty rad. I spent the weekend watching both in the glorious city of Worcester, Massachusetts. To get to Worcester, I had to to take a bus. Concord Trailways to be specific, and as any New England bus-rider knows, it's the Cadillac of bus services. My coach was no exception, for as I was waiting in the cool sea breeze at the Rockland Ferry Terminal, up pulled the bus from the future! I checked. The flux capacitor was in perfect working condition, and I was in for an interstate journey of wonder and magic! The first thing I noticed on this future bus - the Busulator 8000 - was the fact that this astonishing marvel of engineering came equipped with not just TV screens, but large, flatscreen, plasma displays! So large, and so numerous were these TV screens, that there was literally no way to not view them! Even looking out the window was merely an exercise in watching Dan In Real Life in mirror image. That's right. Watching Dan In Real Life was unavoidable, because in the future ALL MEDIOCRE FAMILY COMEDIES WITH TIRED THEMES ARE MANDATORY! I know many of you are thinking certain insulting things about me in your head. Words like, dumb, idiot, pea-brained or even suspected rapist, are flitting trough your superior minds as you think to yourself, "Let's get serious asshole (another word). Clearly you could have simply shut your eyes and imagined that Dan In Real Life was really about an alien robot (named Dan of course) who through some kooky circumstances becomes the drummer for an Icelandic heavy metal band named REEL LIPHE (the proud Icelandic people are known to be accomplished fishermen), and they all set about to conquer planet earth using lasers, chainsaws, and swords forged in hell from the tears of Satan himself (yes, Satan does cry!)" Well you would think that, and you would be wrong! Who's the smart guy now, big brain? You see this time traveling wunder-bus played the audio from the DVD player (a mother fucking BLU-RAY player!) right through the bus' PA system! Holy shit! Color me delighted, because even when I played some Scandinavian viking metal at a volume that hurt my eardrums through my iPod, I could still hear Dan in Real Life echoing off the walls of my mystical, state of the art, tomorrow bus of misery. I have never longed more for the the dingy, grey, hepatitis-coated embraced of a Greyhound's seat.

Spike is airing Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace right now. I'm feeling under the weather, it's a Friday night, and I have basic cable. I may as well tune in.

I was hoping I would be able to watch this movie with a fresh perspective. The crushing disappointment and resulting outrage since George Lucas first plunged a searing lightsaber in to our collective hearts had subsided. Midi-chlorians aside, the beloved original series remained rather unscathed, and in theory The Phantom Menace has a lot going for it.

There are Jedis played by Liam Neeson, Ewan McGregor, and Sam -fucking- Jackson. It has that white-knuckle pod racing scene. It's got R2 and 3PO.

And of course, there's this guy:


So how does Phantom Menace hold up nearly a decade later?

Sigh. The old wounds may have healed, but the scars remain. Everything begins well enough. The score, the retro-industrial production design of the droids and ships, and the enormous attention to detail given to the props and costumes make me want to believe so badly that I can enjoy this movie.

Then Jar Jar comes flopping into the film, and my blood begins to boil all over again. Jar Jar Binks (even his name makes me want to beat up a school child) and his sickening, racist , high-pitched babbling single-handedly ruin this film.

Yes, there is plenty else to complain about. The plot is full of holes, and much of the acting (notably Natalie Portman and the little kid who plays Anakin) is rather cringe-worthy.

But us sci-fi fans can forgive obvious plot holes, and we've all had to reconcile Mark Hamill's acting long ago (Tashi station? Power converters?).

But Jar Jar. JAR JAR! Oh how I hate him.

This is why I have a proposition for George Lucas. Seeing how Mr. Lucas enjoys tinkering with his old movies so much, how about a completely new voice-over for Jar Jar Binks?

Think about it. He is a completely digital character anyway. It would be no problem to recast Jar Jar Binks with, well, anybody! Instead of the bumbling, inane Jar Jar we've all come to loathe, why not say, Chris Rock? He'd still be high energy and bombastic, but at least he'd have a soul.

If you wanted to change the whole tone of the movie, you could cast Christopher Walken or better yet Law & Order's Sam Waterson as Jar Jar.

Hell, you could cast Glen Danzig, or the singer of a Swedish metal band, and really make Jar Jar kick ass.

And of course if you wanted to scare everyone shitless, you could always cast Javier Bardem.

For all of its faults, I believe the entire Star Wars prequel series could be vastly improved with just a few tweaks to the audio tracks. Re-cast Jar Jar Binks, eliminate all the superfluous, silly battle droid banter, and mute 90% of Natalie Portman's dialog, and you have some halfway watchable movies.

In the seventh Star Trek movie: Generations, the crew off the USS Enterprise-D find themselves locked in battle with a rogue Klingon ship, trying desperately to retaliate, as the Klingons bombard the Enterprise with fire. As you can imagine, as in nearly every episode, in every incarnation of the series, there's a lot of this happening: And this, has always baffled me. Every time there is a space battle, the Enterprise is fired upon, and no matter where the ship is hit, control panels on the bridge just start exploding left and right. These control panels are essentially giant iPhones, and although Apple has had problems with exploding products lately, I still don't see why a direct photon torpedo hit to the aft shuttle bay would start a chain reaction so great, that it would cause a control panel to explode with such force that it actually propels an adult male 15 feet through the air! That's like running over a squirrel in an 18 wheeler, and instantly having the steering wheel melt in your hands, and the windshield shatter.

Hey everyone! Meet my new girlfriend!



Her head makes up over a third of her entire body!

It's just baffling that 6 year olds are playing with what essentially amounts to a porn star doll (nsfw).

Of course when that hussy Barbie came on the scene in 1959, mothers were horrified at Barbie's salacious physique, and fathers were horrified at Barbie's "career woman" outfits.

Even though Barbie's unrealistic image (and her materialistic pursuits) can still make us cringe (to say nothing of those in the Muslim world) the girl is practically a Mormon compared to Bratz.

Oh well. I mean what's the worst that could happen?

The 4 year old and I have made hamburgers out of Play Doh, built robots out of Legos that have to go to the "Robot Hospital" when their legs fall off (they also convalesce in the "Robot Hot Tub"), danced to Beck, and now we're on our way to get hot dogs. 

Who knew shiftless, unemployed 20-somethings and 4 year olds had so much in common?

Heads up kids! It's time for a fat dose of info-tainment comin' up side your head!

This is in no way, actually true. The following is neither informative, nor entertaining, nor will it be coming anywhere near the side of your head. It will likely be coming somewhere to the the rear of your head by way of your optic nerves, unless you have the misfortune of being a blind person, and then this will, in fact, be coming to the side of your head via sound waves. Unless, inexplicably, you have transposed this blog post into braille, and then you have the misfortune of being far too stupid for me to to ever acknowledge you again. (Consider this condescending "shout-out" the digital equivalent of a pity fuck).

Hey! So remember how I have been living in my old bedroom in the house I grew up in (complete with faux, 70's wood paneling) geeking the fuck out and writing dissertations about the outdated technology of the original Star Trek series? Do you!? Did you take pity, and shake your head, and regret ever knowing me?

Well some dude (with great taste) named Stephen Hunt found said dissertation, and published it on his website, Science Fiction Crowsnest. And thank you for asking, yes this site is a partner of the Arthur C Clark Awards.

So that's exciting!

Also exciting: I am typing this from a rather swank apartment in Brooklyn, New York. I've been traveling all day, and now I plan on finishing this post, watching My Neighbor Totoro, and going to bed. I'm here for the next week or so, so... fyi.

Ok, I'm tired! Bye everybody! Stay beautiful!

Dear internet!

A friend of mine has recently got a computer and the internet for the first time! This man has been celebrating his "twenty eighth" birthday every year now for about a decade, if that gives you any clue as to what age we're dealing with here.

What I need from you dear friends, is a list of interesting, quirky, entertaining and easy to understand websites that an internet neophyte can manage to comprehend.

Remember, this person has never used the internet before, so even if something stopped being funny in 1998 it's all shiny and new to this individual. He also resides in Seattle, so anything regional should pertain to Jet City.

Ok, there is your assignment. Go to it internet!

Guess what you didn't do yesterday! Spend the afternoon in this place:



This here is the Higgins Armory Museum. It's "the only museum in the Western Hemisphere entirely devoted to the study and display of arms and armor".

Fuck yeah it is! This place has literally hundreds of suits of armor. Mostly Western European, but the museum also has a few East Asian and African examples of ancient armor and weapons, as well as actual gladiator helmets from the first century.

Along with the suits of armor, there were more swords and halberds than I have ever seen in my life.

Also, if you've ever wondered what the mecca for middle-aged renaissance fair goers is, this is the place. My girlfriend and I had our ears talked off by an overly enthusiastic (and a little overly rotund to be fitting into a suit of armor) man in his late forties, who just had to drop the fact that the History Channel was coming to film the museum and quit possibly... him!

Worcester doesn't really have a whole lot to boast, but if you're ever in the area, this is a must see.
BARACK OBAMA BUILT YOU A ROBOT
For those of you who still think Obama is nothing more than a stuffed suit, go ahead and take a look at this Daily Kos piece detailing Obama's record in the US Senate.

Home is where the heart is. In my case, that heart has been torn, still beating from my chest and slowly lowered into a jar of acid as I - and through some arcane use of black magic, my unborn children from the future - watch in horror and misery. 

After nearly three years of living agreeably in the city of Seattle, I have returned here to mid-coast Maine to stage the next phase of my life. This next phase will take me to Brooklyn, New York, and I couldn't be more overcome with excitement and anticipation. 

The interim however, leaves me here. Jobless, penniless, and without even the simple luxury of being able to take a hot shower. If my father of 79 years can shower twice a week in the manner of a Korean War era soldier, then why can't I man up and do the same? 

Most people have to deal with a generation gap between themselves and their parents. I have the pleasure of trying to overcome two. My father is a generally well meaning if slightly cantankerous man, and despite certain extraneous health factors, is in remarkable shape for someone who is nearly 80 years old. 

Though we have an amiable relationship, it goes without saying that we clash constantly over the slightest minutia. From politics to whether or not a dollop of cranberry sauce equals a full serving of vegetables, we bicker and become exasperated with the other perpetually through the day. 

Thankfully I was able to hook up cable television in my bedroom. This is a new concept for me, this cable TV. I'll try not to appear as one of those holier-than-thou, "I don't watch TV because I am too busy pouring over The Utne Reader and looking down on those base enough to extract some sort of enjoyment from a flickering box of regurgitated schlock" people. On the contrary. I'm sort of excited to get better acquainted with this endless sea of regurgitated schlock. I finally found out who Hanna Montana is, and with any luck, I'll figure out what this Tina Tequila person is all about. 

What I really need, urgently, is a job. I need money, and I need it now. I need first, last and deposit for a decent apartment near Prospect Park. I need gas money and bus fare so I can visit my girl in Massachusetts. I need to take this opportunity to pick up the pieces of my life that I have dropped along the way, and more than anything else, I need to find a place where I can take a long, hot shower.
That said, I am quitting. For good. For real. Check it out! Thanks to for the banner.

Last night was my final shift at Smokin' Pete's BBQ. Here's the cake they got me: In case you can't make it out, the text reads "Live Long and Prosper". The little guy on the cake is Odo from Deep Space Nine, who was picked up for 89 cents at Archie McPhee.

Ok, so I guess I got a little bit of the Cloverfield fever. It's a rather haunting movie, and I couldn't stop thinking about it all day. So of course when it came time to do the "specials" board at work, this was the result: Yeah, they tend to try and keep me away from the specials board, as I tend to pollute it with my pathetic geekiness: This doesn't even have anything to do with eating food. It's not even drawn well! I'm hopeless I tell you.

So I just got home from seeing Cloverfield. Here's my review. If you're not familiar with the plot, basically it's about this giant monster. The monster is really sad. There's also this kindly old professor named Burgstrom T. Skittlesworth. Skittlesworth has a pregnant chimpanzee named Choo Choo. Choo Choo gives birth and there are baby monkeys EVERYWHERE! Then they all have a party, and everyone eats bananas. Eeep eeep!! The real news is that there is a teaser trailer for STAR TREK XI!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! YAY YAY!!! God, seeing movies alone in the afternoon makes me batshit.
Cheers!

Due to some new circumstances, I am forced to leave Seattle at the end of JANUARY instead of February, as originally planned. This means I have less than TWO WEEKS LEFT IN SEATTLE. This also means that I have to get rid of all my shit ASAP. I'll be posting soon what I am getting rid of, and if you're a friend, it's yours for cheap/free. Gah! Anyway, we should hang out. Daily Kos has a great, four part series showing a side of presidential candidate Ron Paul that his fervent supporters may not be aware of. Such as excerpts from his self published newsletter The Ron Paul Political Report. This, from a 3,700-word racist tirade written by Paul in 1992:

Regardless of what the media tell us, most white Americans are not going to believe that they are at fault for what blacks have done to cities across America. The professional blacks may have cowed the elites, but good sense survives at the grass roots. Many more are going to have difficultly avoiding the belief that our country is being destroyed by a group of actual and potential terrorists -- and they can be identified by the color of their skin. This conclusion may not be entirely fair, but it is, for many, entirely unavoidable.

Indeed, it is shocking to consider the uniformity of opinion among blacks in this country. Opinion polls consistently show that only about 5% of blacks have sensible political opinions, i.e. support the free market, individual liberty, and the end of welfare and affirmative action.... Given the inefficiencies of what D.C. laughingly calls the "criminal justice system," I think we can safely assume that 95% of the black males in that city are semi-criminal or entirely criminal.

If your stomach can handle it, check out the entire article. Though Ron Paul stated for the first time publicly on the PBS program NOW that he does not want money from white supremacist groups, he nevertheless has no plans on returning donations from hate mongers. Aside from his barely concealed racism, here are some more issues that should give progressive/liberal/lefty folk pause: (again, from Daily Kos) Ron Paul:
is pro-life. is in the pocket of oil companies and voted to drill in ANWR supports repealing birthright citizenship voted against reauthorizing the Voting Rights Act of 1965 supports the Defense Of Marriage Act supports prayer in school
And on and on. Come lefties! Do you really want to throw your time, energy and money away on this guy?
